verse_commentaries.commentary: The psalm opens with the rare superscription 'תְּהִלָּה' (tehillah) - only here and Ps 119:171. The immediate juxtaposition 'אֱלוֹהַי הַמֶּלֶךְ' (my God the king) is striking - personal possession + cosmic sovereignty. The phrase 'לְעוֹלָם וָעֶד' appears twice in first two verses, creating immediate emphasis on eternality.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes personal-to-cosmic tension central to thesis
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: tə-hil-lāh lə-dhā-widh 'a-rō-mim-khā 'e-lō-hay ham-me-lekh wa-'a-vā-rə-khāh shim-khā lə-ʿō-lām wā-ʿedh

verse_commentaries.commentary: Perfect parallel structure with v.1 but shifts to daily practice 'בְּכׇל־יוֹם'. The repetition of exact phrase 'לְעוֹלָם וָעֶד' creates obsessive emphasis on eternality. Note the progression: extol → bless (v.1) then bless → praise (v.2).
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes temporal comprehensiveness matching spatial comprehensiveness

verse_commentaries.commentary: Dramatic shift from personal vow to cosmic statement. 'מְהֻלָּל מְאֹד' (much acclaimed) is intensive praise language. The phrase 'אֵין חֵקֶר' (no searching/fathoming) appears elsewhere only in Job 5:9, 9:10, 36:26 - divine incomprehensibility theme.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes transcendence pole of divine kingship
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: gā-dhōl yə-hō-wāh ūm-hul-lāl mə-'ōdh wə-ligh-dhul-lā-thō 'ēy-n khē-qer

verse_commentaries.commentary: First 'דּוֹר לְדוֹר' (generation to generation) phrase - crucial intergenerational motif. Verbs shift to imperfect (יְשַׁבַּח, יַגִּידוּ) suggesting ongoing action. The pairing of 'מַעֲשֶׂיךָ' (works) and 'גְּבוּרֹתֶיךָ' (mighty acts) becomes central vocabulary.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Introduces temporal expansion crucial to thesis
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: du-ōr lə-dhōr yə-sha-bakh ma-ʿa-sey-khā ūgh-vū-rō-they-khā ya-giy-dhū

verse_commentaries.commentary: Extraordinary accumulation of glory terms: 'הֲדַר כְּב֣וֹד הוֹדֶ֑ךָ' - splendor, glory, majesty. This triple stack is unusual. Shift to first person 'אָשִׂיחָה' (I will meditate/recite) returns to personal dimension. 'נִפְלְאֹתֶיךָ' (wonders) is classic divine acts vocabulary.
figurative_analysis: divine majesty as overwhelming visual splendor
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Personal meditation on cosmic majesty - bridges individual/universal

verse_commentaries.commentary: The word 'עֱזוּז' (might/power) is rare - only here and few other places. 'נוֹרְאֹתֶיךָ' (awesome deeds) paired with 'גְדֻלָּתְךָ' (greatness). Note textual issue: ketiv has plural suffix, qere has singular. Third person 'יֹאמֵרוּ' (they shall speak) vs first person 'אֲסַפְּרֶנָּה' (I will recount).
figurative_analysis: awesome deeds as fearsome divine power
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Others speak, I recount - communal/individual praise dynamic

verse_commentaries.commentary: Unique verb 'יַבִּיעוּ' (they shall pour forth/gush) for praise - liquid metaphor for speech. 'זֵכֶר רַב־טוּבְךָ' (remembrance of abundant goodness) - memory as active celebration. 'יְרַנֵּנוּ' (sing joyously) is exuberant praise vocabulary. Righteousness and goodness paired.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Abundant goodness generates abundant praise - proportional response

verse_commentaries.commentary: Classic divine character formula echoing Exodus 34:6-7. Exact sequence: 'חַנּוּן וְרַחוּם... אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם וּגְדׇל־חָֽסֶד'. This is systematic theology, not spontaneous praise. Central pivot verse after mighty acts (vv.4-7) and before universal scope (vv.9ff).
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Theological center - character grounds both mighty acts and cosmic care

verse_commentaries.commentary: Double 'kol' (all) - 'לַכֹּל' and 'כׇּל־מַעֲשָֽׂיו'. First universal statement in psalm. 'טוֹב' (good) is simple but comprehensive. 'רַחֲמָיו' (mercies) connects to 'רַחוּם' (compassionate) in v.8. Universal scope dramatically expands from Israel to cosmos.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Critical transition from character to universal application

verse_commentaries.commentary: Universal praise 'כׇּל־מַעֲשֶׂיךָ' (all your works) vs particular 'וַחֲסִידֶיךָ' (your faithful ones). Two different groups with two different responses: יוֹדוּךָ (acknowledge/thank) vs יְבָרְכֽוּכָה (bless). Interesting that all creation 'thanks' but faithful ones 'bless'.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Universal participation with special role for faithful

verse_commentaries.commentary: Royal language intensifies: 'כְּבוֹד מַלְכוּתְךָ' (glory of your kingship) and 'גְבוּרָתְךָ' (your might). Both verbs are speech acts: יֹאמֵרוּ (speak) and יְדַבֵּרוּ (declare). Sets up the Ugaritic parallel in vv.12-13.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Royal ideology preparation for cosmic kingship claims

verse_commentaries.commentary: Purpose clause 'לְהוֹדִיעַ לִבְנֵי הָאָדָם' (to make known to human beings) - missionary dimension. Triple royal vocabulary: 'גְּבוּרֹתָיו', 'כְּבוֹד', 'הֲדַר מַלְכוּתוֹ'. Shift from second person (your) to third person (his) - distancing effect for cosmic perspective.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine kingship requires human witness and proclamation
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: lə-hō-dhiy-ʿa  liv-nēy hā-'ā-dhām gə-vū-rō-thāy-w ūkh-vōdh ha-dhar mal-khū-thō

verse_commentaries.commentary: The famous Ugaritic parallel: eternal kingship formula. Chiastic structure: מַלְכוּתְךָ מַלְכוּת (your kingdom is a kingdom) and generational dominion. LXX adds entire extra line (13a) about God's faithfulness - major textual expansion. Missing nun verse in Hebrew acrostic comes here.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Climax of cosmic kingship theology with ancient Near Eastern roots
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: mal-khūth-khā mal-khūth kul-ʿō-lā-miy-m ū-mem-shal-tkhā bəkh-ldu-ōr wā-dhōr

verse_commentaries.commentary: Dramatic shift from cosmic kingship to concrete care. 'סוֹמֵךְ' (supports) and 'זוֹקֵף' (raises up) are physical verbs. 'נֹפְלִים' (falling ones) and 'כְּפוּפִים' (bent over ones) - vulnerable populations. Double 'כׇל' emphasizes universality of care.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine kingship proven through care for vulnerable - anti-imperial ideology

verse_commentaries.commentary: Beautiful image: 'עֵינֵי־כֹל אֵלֶיךָ יְשַׂבֵּרוּ' (eyes of all wait hopefully to you). Universal dependence expressed through eye imagery. 'בְּעִתּוֹ' (in its time) suggests divine timing, not human demand. Food provision as royal responsibility.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Universal dependence on divine provision - economic kingship

verse_commentaries.commentary: Hand imagery: 'פּוֹתֵחַ אֶת־יָדֶךָ' (opening your hand). 'מַשְׂבִּיעַ' (satisfying) suggests complete fulfillment. 'לְכׇל־חַי רָצוֹן' (every living thing with favor/desire) - both biological life and divine pleasure. Generous divine economy.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine generosity as evidence of righteous rule

verse_commentaries.commentary: Character summary with double 'כׇל': 'בְּכׇל־דְּרָכָיו' (in all his ways) and 'בְּכׇל־מַעֲשָֽׂיו' (in all his works). 'צַדִּיק' (righteous) and 'חָסִיד' (faithful/kind) are judicial and relational terms. Ways vs works distinction suggests character vs action.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Universal divine character - righteous rule extends to all domains

verse_commentaries.commentary: Qualified universalism: 'לְכׇל־קֹרְאָיו' (to all who call him) BUT 'בֶאֱמֶת' (in truth). Divine nearness conditional on sincerity. 'קָרוֹב' (near) is intimate presence language. Double 'קֹל' reference creates emphasis on calling.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Universal access but with sincerity condition - qualified inclusivity
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: qā-rōv yə-hō-wāh ləkh-lqō-rə-'āy-w lə-khōl 'a-sher yiq-rā-'u-hū ve-'e-meth

verse_commentaries.commentary: Three-step divine response: 'יַעֲשֶׂה' (fulfills), 'יִשְׁמַע' (hears), 'וְיוֹשִׁיעֵם' (saves them). 'רְצוֹן־יְרֵאָיו' (desires of those who fear him) - fear as reverence. Sequential divine action from desire to deliverance.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Divine responsiveness to reverent worshipers - royal accessibility

verse_commentaries.commentary: Sharp moral dualism: 'אֹהֲבָיו' (those who love him) vs 'הָרְשָׁעִים' (the wicked). 'שׁוֹמֵר' (watches/guards) vs 'יַשְׁמִיד' (destroys). Divine protection/judgment binary. Universal 'כׇל' applies to both groups.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Royal justice requires both protection and judgment

verse_commentaries.commentary: Perfect inclusio with vv.1-2: returns to 'my mouth' and praise. BUT now expands to 'כׇל־בָּשָׂר' (all flesh) - universal participation achieved. 'שֵׁם קׇדְשׁוֹ' (his holy name) adds holiness dimension absent from opening. Completes individual-to-cosmic movement.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Perfect completion of individual-to-cosmic praise trajectory
verse_commentaries.phonetic_transcription: tə-hil-lath yə-hō-wāh yə-dha-ber-piy wiy-vā-rē-khə kul-bā-sār shēm qdhə-shō lə-ʿō-lām wā-ʿedh f

thematic_threads: Acrostic structure with missing nun verse - intentional gap or textual issue?
Sevenfold use of 'kol' (all) creates obsessive universality emphasis
Movement from personal vows (vv.1-3) to intergenerational (vv.4-7) to universal (vv.8-21)
Ugaritic royal formula integration suggests ancient Near Eastern appropriation
Systematic theology (Exodus 34 formula) embedded in praise genre
Sharp shift from cosmic kingship (vv.11-13) to concrete care (vv.14-16)
Moral dualism tension with universal mercy theme
interesting_questions: Why does the psalm use the rare superscription 'תְּהִלָּה' only here and Psalm 119:171?
What is the significance of the missing nun verse in the acrostic - textual accident or intentional theological statement?
How does the triple accumulation 'הֲדַר כְּבוֹד הוֹדֶךָ' function - are these distinct attributes or poetic intensification?
Why does the LXX add an entire extra verse (13a) about divine faithfulness?
How do we reconcile universal divine mercy (v.9) with universal destruction of the wicked (v.20)?
What motivates the dramatic shift from cosmic kingship language (vv.11-13) to concrete care imagery (vv.14-16)?
Why does the psalm borrow Job's 'אֵין חֵקֶר' language for divine incomprehensibility?
What is the theological significance of different praise verbs for creation (thank) versus faithful ones (bless) in verse 10?
How does 'כׇל־בָּשָׂר' (all flesh) in the conclusion relate to the cosmic scope established earlier?
Why integrate the exact Exodus 34:6-7 formula rather than creating original praise language?
synthesis_notes:
TEXTUAL: LXX additions, missing nun verse, ketiv/qere variations
LEXICON: Royal terminology, rare words (tehillah, ezuz, yabi'u), divine epithets
INTERTEXTUAL: Exodus 34 formula usage, Job language borrowing, Ugaritic parallels
THEOLOGICAL: Universal mercy vs divine judgment, individual vs cosmic praise, ancient Near Eastern royal ideology adaptation
